node.title: Religious freedom is not about a contest of rights, but a deeper question of the right to have them
node.alt: A man stands in front of a church
node.description: As this week's debates have shown, the issue of religious freedom versus secular freedom requires a nuance and depth that evades our politics â€“ and is far from peacefully resolved, writes Stan Grant.
node.content:
["Does Australia have a God problem?", "This past week's debate about religious freedom has tested the limits of tolerance, freedom, respect, and rights. Many MPs were motivated by deeply held convictions, but the tone of debate wasn't helped by a heavy dose of political opportunism and partisanship across the aisles of parliament.", "The political right senses an opportunity to expose the left as being weak on faith, calculating it will hurt Labor in multicultural seats, especially in Sydney's west. They paint the left and the progressive politics of identity at its more extreme as dismissive, indeed hostile, to religion.", "Social progressives frame the deeply held beliefs of conservative people of faith on abortion, LGBTIQ issues and euthanasia as discrimination and intolerance rather than matters of faith and conviction.", "Conservatives, meanwhile, sometimes seem more eager to plant the flag of their faith in the defence of intolerance or exclusion than the teachings of love, forgiveness, grace and humility.", "The\u00a0bold assertion of religious freedom\u00a0has also been\u00a0undermined in recent times by the moral failings of many faith groups\u00a0on issues of sexual abuse.", "As this week has shown, the politics of faith and secularism are divisive and seemingly implacable.", "But Australia is not alone when it comes to questions of God.\u00a0", "
The role of faith in the public square
", "Throughout the world faith is a political fault line. Indeed, for liberal democracies it is an existential challenge. It raises questions of who belongs? Where does the public and private begin and end? What is the future of pluralism? Can democracy still effectively govern over diversity?", "From India's hijab ban in some schools, to France's public prohibition of full face veils to Sweden's ban on minarets on mosques, the role of faith in the public square is an incendiary one.", "Political leaders around the world are seizing on religion as a fundamental marker of national identity. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi pursues a virulent Hindu nationalism that is eroding the country's democracy. In Myanmar Buddhist nationalism has inspired the slaughter and mass removal of Rohingya Muslims.", "", "
Vladimir Putin has positioned Orthodox religion as a cornerstone of what it is to be Russian.(Reuters: Sputnik/Mikhail Metzel/Pool\u00a0)
", "The Chinese Communist Party outlaws all Christian churches not authorised, monitored and approved by the state. China has called Islam a mental illness to justify what's been called a genocide against ethnic Muslim Uighurs.", "Political populists like Hungary's Viktor Orban, who has boasted of his illiberal democracy, was once an atheist but now styles himself as the defender of Christianity. He says Western Europe has given up on Christianity; instead he says it had chosen a \"godless cosmos, rainbow families, migration and open societies.\".", "Vladimir Putin has positioned Orthodox religion as a cornerstone of what it is to be Russian. He has lectured the West on the perils of identity politics.", "Like China's Xi Jinping, Putin sees Western liberalism as inherently weak and, to Putin, the erosion of faith is symbolic of that weakness.", "
Is Europe still Christian?
", "This is especially acute in Europe. French scholar Olivier Roy has questioned if Europe is, in fact, still Christian. Roy says \"secularisation has given way to large scale dechristianisation\".", "There is now, he says, \"a serious crisis surrounding European identity and the place of religion in the public sphere\".", "In a recent Atlantic magazine feature journalist Rachel Donadio asked: Why is France so afraid of God? In France, she says the idea of la\u00efcit\u00e9 \"defines the most ferociously contested battle lines in contemporary France\".", "La\u00efcit\u00e9, she says, does not establish the freedom of religion, but sometimes freedom from religion. Donadio writes: \"The term has come to express a uniquely French insistence that religion, along with religious symbols and dress, should be absent from the public sphere.\"", "", "
In France,\u00a0La\u00efcit\u00e9 does not establish the freedom of religion, but sometimes freedom from religion, says\u00a0Rachel Donadio.(AP: Michel Euler)
", "Rendering unto Caesar what is Caesar's and to God what is God's has been a defining struggle for liberalism.\u00a0", "In his landmark book, A Secular Age, philosopher Charles Taylor posed this fundamental question: \"Why was it virtually impossible not to believe in God in, say, 1500 in our Western society, while in 2000 many of us find this not only easy, but even inescapable?\"", "For many people, he says, the answer is simple: \"Modern civilisation cannot but bring about a death of God.\"", "Modernity itself is built upon the elevation of the individual, the rupture of tradition, and the goal of human flourishing.", "As Taylor writes, secularism means that \"for the first time in history a purely self-sufficient humanism came to be a widely available option\".", "This is a humanism, he says, \"accepting no final goals beyond human flourishing. Of no previous society was this true.\"", "
The rise of secularism
", "The rise of secularism is seeded in the 18th century Enlightenment. Giant figures like David Hume questioned the rationality of religion and wondered how the existence of God was consistent with human suffering.", "Hume is often hailed as a philosophical hero to atheists. He is much more subtle than that, and argued for politeness in public debate, warning that \"reason is the slave of the passions\". How true that is today.", "The Enlightenment was framed by debate about God versus society. From Thomas Hobbes' idea of the Leviathan\u00a0\u2014\u00a0the all-powerful state which rules above religion \u2014\u00a0to John Locke, who sought to reconcile faith and reason.", "Liberal democracies that emerged out of the Enlightenment embraced the doctrine of separation of church and state. But the globalised, pluralist, multicultural 21st century asks more difficult questions that 18th century philosophy struggles to answer.", "Charles Taylor has called this a disenchanted age: \"We can rationalise the world, expel the mystery from it.\"", "Political utopia has sought to fill the void.\u00a0", "Political philosopher Judith Shklar traced the decline of political faith, identifying \"the alienated soul\" who has \"lost all faith in the beliefs of the past, having been disillusioned by skepticism, but is unable to find a new home for its spiritual longings in the present or future\".", "Liberalism, Shklar said, had become \"unsure of its moral basis\". It is a society built on rationalisation and bureaucratisation.", "Inevitably there is an emptiness, filled today by identity-based politics seeking belonging around shared suffering and injustice, and people of faith for whom divine scripture cannot be contracted away.", "Both identity and faith are a response to a world stripped of meaning. They each seek comfort and assurance in an age of moral and political complexity and relativism.", "Indeed, they share things in common. Identity groups can be as doctrinaire and rigid as some conservative people of faith.\u00a0", "
Religion as a weapon\u00a0up for grabs
", "To philosopher and theologian John Milbank, we have traded hierocratic rule (authority of the church) for conciliatory contractual rule.", "Secularity itself, Milbank says, relies on an \"ontology of violence\"; it \"assumes the priority of force and tells us how this force is best managed and confined by counter-force\".", "So, we have what we see in the world: a contest of power. At its more benign it is a peaceful democratic contest of ideas. But at its worst it gives rise to actual violence and extremism.", "Radical Islamists and white supremacists both use religion as a weapon.", "", "
The government's religious discrimination bill was put before the lower house this week.(ABC News: Matt Roberts)
", "John Milbank argues that Christianity itself can reconcile virtue with difference in a way that is \"living together in agreement, rather than mutual toleration\". He says it is a justice of a \"real peace, that is more than just suspended warfare\".", "In Australia we have arrived at a position of suspended political warfare, but the issue of religious freedom versus secular freedom is far from peacefully resolved.", "It requires a nuance and depth that evades our politics. The questions of faith go to the very heart of the modern secular liberal project.", "All over the world it is up for grabs, hijacked by hatred and exploited by demagogues.", "It is not, as it has been framed here, simply a contest of rights. It is, as the philosopher Hannah Arendt put it, the more existential question of the right to have rights.", "Stan Grant is the ABC's international affairs analyst and presents China Tonight on Monday at 9:35pm on ABC TV, and Tuesday at 8pm on the ABC News Channel and is a co-presenter of Q&A."]
